bibl.title: Letter from [Ralph Cooper Hutchison] to J. Howard Pew, April 11, 1940

div1.p: This is [Hutchison's] draft letter, with Hench's autograph corrections, to the president of the Sun Oil Company, asking his assistance in granting Moran time off to attend the Founders' Day ceremony at Washington and Jefferson College.

div1.head: Letter from [Ralph Cooper Hutchison] to J. Howard Pew, April 11, 1940
div1.opener:
Washington, Pa.,April 11, 1940.
Mr. J. Howard Pew,
President, Sun Oil Company,
Philadelphia, Pa.
My dear Mr. Pew:
div1.p:
I am taking the liberty of writing to you to seek your good
offices in a matter of great importance to this College. On October
--- WASHINGTON & JEFFERSON will inaugurate “THE LAZEAR HALL OF CHEMISTRY”
which will be dedicated to the memory of Doctor Jesse W. Lazear, one of
the most distinguished alumni of this college. Dr. Lazear as a member
of the Yellow Fever Board appointed by the Surgeon General of the Army,
on May 24, 1900, became a martyr to science while engaged in yellow
fever experiments in Cuba, with the other immortals Walter Reed, James
Carroll and Aristides Agramonte. This college feels justly proud of the
fact that Dr. Lazear's preparatory education was obtained within its
walls and in token thereof dedicates its new Hall of Chemistry to his
memory.

Need
much
modification
P S H

Dr. Philip S. Hench, a distingushed member of the MAYO CLINIC,
Rochester, Minn., will deliver the principal dedicatory address. Doctor
Hench has been accumulating data since 1937 on the history of yellow
fever, up to and including the year of its conquest, 1900. Within a few
years he plans to publish his findings in book form in which will be set
forth the respective parts played in the “Conquest of Yellow Fever” by
Reed, Finlay, Lazear, Carroll and Agramonte. It was while infecting
mosquitoes in the yellow fever ward of Las Animas Hospital, Havana, that
Dr. Lazear contracted the dread disease, succumbing to it on September
25, 1900.

So much by way of explanation. Dr. Hench has recently visited
the scenes of Dr. Lazear's last activities, carrying out his investigations
on the “field of battle” in which he reports valuable cooperation on the
part of Mr. Moran, your Cuban representative, who knew Dr. Lazear very
well and had seen him only a few days before he contracted fatal yellow
fever. WASHINGTON & JEFFERSON would feel honored to have Mr. Moran who (ie Maas) was one of the first to volunteer to receive experimental yellow fever
present for the date of the inauguration of the Lazear Memorial. When
this was suggested to him by Dr. Hench he expressed a sincere desire to
participate, at the same time stating that, for economic reasons, he
would be compelled to forego the honor. Dr. Hench suggested that the
matter of expense of his trip North could possibly be arranged, where-
upon another obstacle presented itself. He told Dr. Hench that he had
taken a vacation of thirty days last year and that he could not, as a
matter of delicacy, apply for another vacation this year. As to the
latter obstacle, you alone could decide and we would be very grateful to
you if it could be overcome. (As to his travel expenses, I feel reasonably
sure we will find a way before October.)
